div.class: col-sm-12 col-md-12 text-center o_colored_level col-lg-10 col-12

div.h5: The nation's single reference point for localised emission factors data

section.style: position: relative; background-image: linear-gradient(0deg, rgb(148, 189, 123) 9%, rgb(46, 139, 87) 100%);

div.class: col-12 col-sm-12 col-md-12 col-lg-12 mb32 text-center o_colored_level o_animate o_animate_on_scroll o_anim_slide_in o_anim_from_bottom pt80 pb40

span.font: We aim to empower Singapore businesses to accelerate their net zero transition. We do so by providing localised Singapore-specific emission factors data, so that businesses will be empowered to track and report their greenhouse gas emissions more easily and accurately, saving time and effort. This will, in turn, help businesses develop a better understanding of the carbon footprint of operations and value chains, identify their emission hotspots, make informed sustainability decisions based on actionable data, and work more effectively towards reducing emissions.

div.class: col-12 col-sm-12 col-md-12 col-lg-12 mb32 text-center o_colored_level pt0 pb32
div.h2:
How to Measure Your Carbon Emissions:
A Step-by-Step Guide
div.h6:
"The journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step."
By measuring your organisation's greenhouse gas emissions (also known as carbon footprint), you can identify areas where you can make changes to decarbonise. This step-by-step guide walks you through the process of calculating your greenhouse gas emissions.

div.p: Every business has processes, products, or services that​ generate greenhouse gas emissions. The Greenhouse Protocol Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard categorises emissions into Scope 1 (direct emissions), Scope 2 (indirect emissions from the consumption of purchased electricity, heat or steam), and Scope 3 emissions (other indirection emissions from a company's upstream and downstream activities).

i.class: fa fa-lightbulb-o rounded-circle s_timeline_icon fa-1x text-o-color-4

div.p: For most small- and medium-sized enterprises and for many​ larger companies, Scope 1 emissions come from​ based on the purchased quantities of commercial​ fuels (e.g. natural gas). Scope 2 emissions will​ primarily be calculated from metered electricity​ consumption. Scope 3 GHG emissions will​
primarily be calculated from activity data such as mass of fuel use or passenger miles travelled by employees.

i.class: fa fa-file rounded-circle s_timeline_icon fa-1x text-o-color-4

div.p:
Refer to the SEFR to select the emission factor for each of your activities. Alternatively, use a digital carbon calculator solution (a list of solutions which will be incorporating SEFR data is available in the
NetZeroHub.SG
Resource Portal).

i.class: fa fa-search rounded-circle s_timeline_icon fa-1x text-o-color-4

div.p: Multiply your activity data with the emission factor to get the emission data. Sum up all your emissions within Scope 1, Scope 2 and Scope 3 to get your organisation's greenhouse gas inventory.

i.class: fa fa-bar-chart-o rounded-circle s_timeline_icon fa-1x text-o-color-4

section.class: o_colored_level pb72 pt72 parallax s_parallax_is_fixed s_parallax_no_overflow_hidden

div.class: col-12 col-sm-12 col-md-12 col-lg-12 o_colored_level pt32

div.h2:
The Future is Carbon Conscious:
Understand Your Emissions to Stay Ahead
div.p:
"You can't manage what you can't measure." Regulators, investors, financial institutions, customers, employees and other stakeholders are requiring organisations to measure their greenhouse gas emissions as part of climate-related disclosures. By developing a better understanding of the carbon footprint of your operations and value chains, you will be able to identify your organisation's emission hotspots, make informed sustainability decisions based on actionable data, and work more effectively towards reducing emissions."
Start and make further progress on your decarbonisation journey with us. Covering a range of activities and sectors, we provide localised Singapore-specific emission factors data to track and report your greenhouse gas emissions more easily and accurately, saving your time and effort.

a.class: text-600 text-decoration-none position-relative faq_title pe-2 fw-bold o_default_snippet_text collapsed

div.div: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency defines an emission factor as “a representative value that attempts to relate the quantity of a pollutant released to the atmosphere with an activity associated with the release of that pollutant.

a.class: text-600 text-decoration-none position-relative pe-2 faq_title fw-bold o_default_snippet_text collapsed

div.a: Where do I download the emission factors data?
div.div:
You may download emission factors data by going to our
Data Page  
Click on "Export All" button – downloads all data which is available on the SEFR; or
Click on "Export As" button - downloads data which you have selected using our search filters.
Please note that only registered users are able to download data. Not registered?
Sign up
for free today!

a.class: text-600 text-decoration-none position-relative pe-2 faq_title fw-bold o_default_snippet_text collapsed

div.div:
Emission factors (EFs, also known as conversion factors) are critical in calculating greenhouse gas emissions (also known as carbon footprint) associated with a unit of activity.
To estimate emissions, an EF is multiplied by the corresponding activity data (e.g. amount of electricity consumed). The basic formula is:
Activity data x EF = Greenhouse gas emissions
For example, if a company purchased and consumed 500kWh of electricity from the grid, and the corresponding EF is 0.4168 kgCO2-eq per kWh, then the greenhouse gas emissions would be 500 kWh * 0.4168 kgCO2-eq per kWh = 208.4 kgCO2-eq.

a.class: text-600 text-decoration-none position-relative pe-2 faq_title fw-bold o_default_snippet_text collapsed

page.

col-12 col-sm-12 col-md-12 col-lg-10 oe_structure oe_empty s_faq_collapse

div.p: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency defines an emission factor as “a representative value that attempts to relate the quantity of a pollutant released to the atmosphere with an activity associated with the release of that pollutant.

For greenhouse gases, EFs are expressed as the mass of greenhouse gases emitted per unit of the emissions-producing activity. For example, kilograms of carbon dioxide-equivalent (kgCO2-eq) emitted per kWh of electricity purchased from the grid.
Emission factors (EFs, also known as conversion factors) are critical in calculating greenhouse gas emissions (also known as carbon footprint) associated with a unit of activity.
To estimate emissions, an EF is multiplied by the corresponding activity data (e.g. amount of electricity consumed). The basic formula is:
Activity data x EF = Greenhouse gas emissions

For example, if a company purchased and consumed 500kWh of electricity from the grid, and the corresponding EF is 0.4168 kgCO2-eq per kWh, then the greenhouse gas emissions would be 500 kWh * 0.4168 kgCO2-eq per kWh = 208.4 kgCO2-eq.
Please refer to our user guide on "Data notes and disclaimers".

div.p: Please refer to our user guide on "Data notes and disclaimers".

div.a: Where can I create a new account?

div.p:
You can register for a free account
here.

div.a: Where do I download the emission factors data?

div.p:
You may download emission factors data by going to our
Data
page:
Click on "Export All" button – downloads all data which is available on the SEFR; or
Click on "Export As" button - downloads data which you have selected using our search filters.
Please note that only registered users are able to download data. Not registered? Sign up for free today!

div.a: Can I share my search result to others?

div.p:
You can share the data which you have selected using our search filters, by clicking on the "Share Data" button on the
Data
page.
Please note that users must be registered and have a valid account in the SEFR portal to be able to view, share, and download emission factors data.

div.a: I am using a digital carbon calculator solution to perform greenhouse gas emissions calculations for my company. Would I be able to benefit from SEFR data?

div.p: SEFR reaches out to a range of digital carbon calculator solutions to partner with them.

div.a: Where can I submit feedback, make suggestions, or ask further questions?

div.p:
Please drop us a message through our
Contact Us
page.

div.h6:
Get access to a comprehensive set of standardised local emission factors for more informed decision
making to reduce your company's carbon footprint.

div.h5: Align Your Values and Build Trust
div.p: Demonstrate your commitment to sustainability and align with the values of your employees and customers. The SEFR Portal provides the data to back up your environmental claims.

Leverage transparent emission reporting to differentiate and appeal to the growing market of consumers demanding sustainable products and services. The SEFR Portal makes it easy to quantify and communicate your environmental impact.

Futureproof your organisation by proactively managing climate-related risks and opportunities. The SEFR Portal equips you with the tools to accurately measure, monitor, and report your carbon footprint - a critical component of long-term value creation.

div.class: col-12 col-sm-12 col-md-12 col-lg-12 mb32 text-center
div.h6:
Explore our latest carbon emission news and insights to stay informed about the current trends and impacts
on our environment.

div.p: The Government has launched the SG Green Plan 2030 which aims to make Singapore a carbon trading and services hub.
In 2020, Singapore saw a significant reduction in emissions compared to previous years, continuing a trend of gradual decline.
Singapore announced its national hydrogen strategy to develop low-carbon hydrogen as a key energy source
26 October, 2022
Singapore proposes raising carbon tax to S$25 per tonne for greenhouse gas emissions in 2024 and 2025.
8 November, 2022

div.h2:
How to Measure Your Carbon Emission:
A Step-by-Step Guide
div.h6: Understanding and reducing your carbon emission is an important step in addressing climate change. By measuring your carbon footprint, you can identify areas where you can make changes to decrease your environmental impact. This step-by-step guide will walk you through the process of calculating your carbon emission and provide strategies for lowering your overall carbon footprint.

div.h5: Understand the Basics of Carbon Footprinting
div.p: Find out more about what is carbon footprint and what are the key contributors to your carbon emission.
Get access to the emission factor data for sustainable reporting.
Utilise our partnered carbon emission calculator to estimate your carbon emission based on the information you provide.
Review the breakdown of your carbon footprint identify areas where to reduce your carbon footprint and deploy effective sustainability strategies.

Singapore Emission Factors Registry (SEFR) Portal mission is to support local businesses to generate more accurate emission inventory that is reflective of Singapore’s conditions and empower them to make informed decisions on how to reduce carbon footprint on their environmental impact.

div.class: col-12 col-sm-12 col-md-12 col-lg-12 mt32 text-center
col-12 col-sm-12 col-md-12 col-lg-12 mb64 text-center
div.h6: This section provides answers to common questions about carbon emission data and how to use it effectively. The FAQs cover the fundamentals of emission factors, their importance, and how individuals and organisations can leverage this information to measure and reduce their environmental impact. Whether you're new to carbon accounting or looking to expand your knowledge, these FAQs will help you better understand the role of emission data.

div.div: Carbon emission factors are standardized measurements that quantify the amount of greenhouse gas emission associated with specific activities or sources.

a.class: collapsed text-600 text-decoration-none position-relative faq_title fw-bold

div.a: How are carbon emission factors calculated?
div.div:
There are four key steps in calculating emission factors which include:
Data collection on emissions and associated activities
Normalisation of data to consistent units
Calculation of the factor by dividing emissions by activity
Verification and peer review of results.
The general formula is:
Emission Factor = Quantity of Emissions / Activity Level

a.class: collapsed text-600 text-decoration-none position-relative faq_title fw-bold

div.a: Where do I download the emission factor data?
div.div:
You can download emission factors data in the Data and Analytics page by clicking on
1. "Export all" button - downloads all available emission factors data as of the last updated date stated 2. "Export data" button - downloads data according to search filters you have selected
Please note that only registered users are able to download emissions factor data.

a.class: collapsed text-600 text-decoration-none position-relative faq_title fw-bold

div.a: Why are carbon emission factors important?
div.div: Carbon emission factors are crucial for standardising the measurement of greenhouse gas emissions per unit of activity, enabling accurate carbon footprint calculations and regulatory compliance. They help organisations identify emission hotspots, track progress towards sustainability goals, and make informed decisions that enhance environmental performance and access to capital.

a.class: collapsed text-600 text-decoration-none position-relative faq_title fw-bold

div.a: How does SEFR review the data for accuracy?
div.div: We ensure data accuracy through a multi-step process that includes validation, cleansing, and regular quality assurance audits. Our commitment to continuous improvement and team training helps maintain the integrity and reliability of our data for all stakeholders

a.class: collapsed text-600 text-decoration-none position-relative faq_title fw-bold

div.a: How often are carbon emission factors updated?
div.div: Emission factors are regularly reviewed and updated as new data becomes available, typically on an annual or biennial basis.

div.h2:
The Future is Carbon Conscious:
Understand Your Emission to Stay Ahead
div.p: Start your carbon-conscious journey with our comprehensive Singapore-specific carbon emission dataset. Covering a range of activities and sectors, our emission factors are regularly updated to reflect the latest energy and transportation trends in the country. Explore this powerful dataset to get a clear picture of your carbon footprint, develop targeted reduction strategies, and demonstrate your commitment to sustainability to customers, investors, and other key stakeholders.

them to measure, manage, and reduce their environmental impact.
